TopicTitle: Is KSP precise enough to establish a GPS or GEO satellite network?

Articles.Content: Well, title is the question. How small the error of the period can we limit to?

You can get a pretty close geosync orbit but it will get messed up after some 100000x warp like when flying a different ship to eeloo or whatever. I wish there was a way to make them perfectly perfect, since I was doing it for remotetech purposes.

I can't exactly answer your question with a number. However, I have a save with a bunch of geosynced sats(edited into orbits with hyperedit). I let time accel run for a few hours on high, came back and they were all still exactly where I left them. No clue if that helps or not.
Can mechjeb do this? As in when you get into orbit it can auto GEO?

I use mechjeb to set my remote tech comms to second accuracy orbital periods. That's still not quite enough which is why I use 6 per orbit. In reality all satellites use station keeping engines and even then only last so many years in their orbit before coming back down.

I've been launching and positioning synced my RemoteTech satellites by hand. The orbits I get are pretty close. My last Kerbin synced satellite looks like

SMA = 3468774.00236996
ECC = 1.05486218982213E-05
INC = 0.000512411442541808

Around that point, the apoapsis and periapsis markers start jumping around, and it's difficult to get the altitude any finer. But once I get them that close, I'm happy to use hyperedit or similar to correct them so they'll stay put. Putting a network of satellites in orbit is fun, but constant maintenance of them is not.
